basedOn.display: MRI BRACH PLEX & AXIL WOW CONT

valueString:
EXAM: MRI BRACHIAL PLEXUS


HISTORY: 


Schwannomatosis, neuropathic pain, muscle weakness, left shoulder pain


Technique: Sagittal, coronal, and axial images were obtained of the left brachial plexus.


Comparison: None


FINDINGS: 


Dr. Nicholas Harn, M.D. has personally reviewed these images and formulated the interpretations and opinions expressed in this report.


There are multiple large T2 hyperintense lesions involving all left cervical and visualized upper thoracic nerve roots. There is artifactual distortion of the cervical fat saturation which limits evaluation of postcontrast imaging. The largest measured lesion is involves the left C3 foraminal and extraforaminal measuring 7 cm x 2.3 cm (series 7#19). 


The root lesions extend to the brachial plexus involving the upper trunk and inferior trunk (series 7#18 and series 7#17, respectively). No involvement of the distal brachial plexus is confidently seen. 


A 2.3 cm lesion in the left cricothyroid notch is present, which could involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve (series 5#27). A small submucosal T2 hyperintense lesion in the lower left tonsillar pillar, with additional scattered smaller submucosal lesions. 


Additional intercostal, intramuscular, and subcutaneous lesions are seen. One is seen in the posterior mediastinum at the level of the carina.
